support to South Africa's racial
policies by the fact that US
investments in South Africa ex-
coed 500 million dollars and
"have increased IS to Is percent
since 1861" The petition further
argues that "as long as the United
States permits American dollars
to bolster minority government.
all of us, as American citizens,
are morally guilty of support
ing apartheid."


The petition thus calls on the
President Ito direct the US Mis-
sion to the UN to support reso-
lutions for boycotts and sane
lions against South Africa: to
place an embargo on American
trade with South Africa; and to
suspend recognition of the South
African Government until such
time as 1t represents all South
Africans.


Among signers of the petition
we're: Martin Luther King, Ed
ward Albee, Lewis Mumford,
Ashley Montagu, Bishop James
Pike, Edward Stone, Mas on Sears
Lionel Trilling, Linus Pauling
and Walter, Victor and Roy Reu-
Their. Among the organiz cation en-
dorsing the petition was the
American Newspaper Guild.

COMMITTEE ON AFRICA SENDS
OUT PETITIONS AGAINST SOUTH AFRICA

NEW YORK A petition de-
manding US faction Against
Apartheid'' in South Africa,
signed by 5000 Americans, was
handed to Ambassador Adlai
Stevenson for transmittal to
President Lyndon Johns on. The
petition was circulated by the
American Committee on Africa
to its own members. Represent
ing the Committee at the 80 min
ute meeting which took place at
the US Mission to the UN were:
James Farmer (CORE), Donald
Harrington Community Church
of Africa), Bayard Rustin (March
on Washington, and Peter Weiss
president, Americana Committee
on Africa).


Ambassador Stevenson pledged
that the petitions would be for
warded to the President accom-
panied with personal note from
him. He also commented gener-
ally on the US position on apar-
theid. Afterwards, US Mission
Press Chief Francis Carpenter
reported that Stevenson had been
"glad to see US. civil rights
leaders concerned with the fate of
South Africa's nom whites"


The petition read, in part:


1.-THE US does continue to lend

Congress has granted funds for another OF the Peace
which has thousands Americans teaching and working In
globe Many being aided by this
program and that better international relations may
be brought about.

country. Here in the land of
plenty millions of existing without food, clothing
Here in the land of free schooling there millions
unable write Here in the land
of opportunity there millions obless


There millions suffering from psychological Illnesses and
illnesses Our mental inst-
filled capacity and millions OF children face
mental disturbances There many
people could aided with simple health in modern
and sanitary country.


We should have organized In every city and
the problems which face us here In
the funds being In distant


could be better used in backyard or front yard

The Russians opened their hearts at Christ
mas time and opened uOide the gates which bar
West Germany from the eastern section. For
the holidays West Germans aOeYe permitted
passes to UiSit families and friends in the Rus
sian controlled area.


thousands SWannbed the offices for per-
maits and the roads leading to the gate sOeye
cI0gged with automobiles. Families and
FRIENDS aOlaO had not seen each other for naapy
months aOeYe reunited at the Christmas season.


During the building Of the pUull and the clos
ing Of the gates there uas much talk of unit
ing East and West Germany. When Chancellor
ET1a0Td Uisited President Lyndon Johnson
last week, he also spoke OF the reunion. D


The VaIl stands as q symbol of not only
the nilitaYistic spirit of the Russians, but Ut
1t IS also q reminder Of the naihtoYistic ma
tiOn which 1t divides. One man mas shot and
killed as he tried to leaUe the eastern sec
tiOn duYi,ag the Christmas rush. The wall re-
mains and the guards are still on duty. There
is little chance that West Germany and East
Germany mill be united soon.

day begin to make mental sum-
maries of all of the ways | in
tend to improve myself for the
incoming year. My resolution
time starts with the beginning of
the new year because | am al
ways doing something which |
could have done better, even on
January the first.


| tried several years ago to
write my list of resolutions on
sheet of paper. AS | wrote and
meditated for three or Jour days,
| discovered there we're too many
things l needed to stop, start
or alter. My resolution writing
ended when | reached number
twenty.


This year l have decided to
forego all writing and just spend
the last few hours of 1868 think
ing. Not about how | could have
improved myself, some situation
or some production, but about the
grand times and glorious NOM
ents have had.


will remember 1868 as hap
py year. will remember 1868
as a busy year. l will remember
1868 as being the year of LA.
(not Los Angeles but less al
leroy reactions for meg. The year
of 80 was a Joy filled year for
me and my spouse. We worked
harder than ever and enjoyed
every minute of the labor of pro-
ducing a weekly newspaper.


Edward and | travelled great
deal and we met many interest
ing persons. l like to see diff
ferent cities and meet different
people. No matter where you 60,
you will make new friends. We
strike up conversations on the
plane, in taxis, in the elevator
or in the hotel lobby. Some of
the people we met in 1868 have
become close friends. So 1868
was a friendly year.


l can't recall what res olutions
had in mind for the year which
is passing on this 3o5th flip of
the calendar. | am sure top on
the list was the desire to remem-
Der the golden rule. am con-
vinced that more happiness can
be brought into your own life
throughout the entire year by fol-
lowing it.


The dying year brought its
share of troubles and woes, also.
My spouse and l had some sad
moments caused by illnesses in
our families. His mother in
England became very i'll. We
called her and she assured us
she was improving. For a little
lady over seventy, she certainly
was perky.


My husband told her we would
visit her in the summer of 1864
and this made her happy. In spite
of the great distance Ed is still
at heart an Englishman. When
ever he gets homesick and calls
England, see a faraway gaze
in his eyes. After talking with
his mother he often starts tell
ing me of his boyhood. In 1868
we made many more travel plans.
1t was year of planning.


How else can one recall year.
A year Is measured in days,
weeks and months. All pass so
quickly that unless we keep a
huge diary, we are unable to
recollect to many events.


So much happens each day until
1t is extremely difficult to keep
one week in mind. We are crea-
lures bent on seeking happiness.
This makes us remember most
of the pleasant things. We instinc-
lively forget or hide the unpleas-

Many reports haze been given on the POLL
tical ability of President Lyndon B. johnson.
HIS knowledge of the nays and sO|aims of laaO-
makers has made him almost a legend sO)aile
he Ines. NesuscasteYs ten the johnson
touch." NesVs stories give accounts Of the
Johnson method of thinning his nay. Cartoon
lists haze used the big Texas handshake theme.
After more than month President Johnson
appears to be in a Qua,adary. He is caught in
maze of political hats. He is attempting to be
many persons at the same time. He is s0mae-
times a liberal, the next time conservative.
He says ne must haze greater military power,
then he announces the shut DOM Of several
bases.


Mn. johnson pressed Congress into the hoh-
day squeeze to min the foreign aid bilL He IN
vited senator's and YebYes entatiUeS to an old
fashioned tvinteY reception. There he tod them
to forget i'll fee hmgs.


Later Mn. Johnson entertained the head Of
the West German government at his ranch IN
Texas. There he pledged support Of the Ey-
hard government. Ey]aayd in return said he
would help the United States min favOT with
the Common Market. After some southern
barbecue Mn. EYhQYd returned home and re-
leased the usual message Of his wonderful
viSit with the president.


our president Vill find that 1t takes more
than southern hospitality to run the country
as an effective executive.
Discussing Arizona Low

THE YEARS END
